displayed_text: Healthcare Professional: He’s having some back pain. Doctor: Right. Family Member: We’re just kind of… Doctor: Show me where. (paper shuffling) Family Member: Yeah that’s what we wanted, that’s what we did. We just did it though. Doctor: Right here? Yeah I know that’s why it’s not. Does this hurt when I push? Patient: Not – a little bit. Doctor: A little bit. Not too bad though. Patient: No. Doctor: Is there anything that brings on the pain? Family Member: Let me tell you, I think sometimes J___ over exerts himself. Patient: I might if I have…

Family Member: Um hum. Doctor: Okay. As much as we can. Patient: Can I sign now, and-? Doctor: Yeah. Patient: When do I have to sign? Doctor: Oh. You have to sign when you are feeling- when you feel comfortable. It’s just that- Patient: I feel comfortable now. I mean. Doctor: Okay. All right. Then I think you should- Patient: As long as we can work around- Doctor: Yeah. We’ll try and work around most of those dates. If, only it becomes a problem, we may have to delay it, doing your second eye or whatever. Family Member: Because it’s all, yeah. Doctor: Yeah.

Patient: Or when I would I brush my teeth. Doctor: Yep. Yep. So is it better now on the medicine? Patient: It’s gone. Family Member 1: So that might happen with this pill now, right? Or we don't know? Doctor: We don't know, anything is possible, but most of it is, you know, it's going to be very cyclical, right? Patient: Right. Doctor: Sort of like this is different than the Elida which is always in your system. You take it every day. The chemo is in your system, but it peaks, you know, kind of seven to 10 days. You're like, “yeah, I don’t feel so great. I'm not gonna run the marathon.” But then you kind of come down and you're like, “oh, okay, great. It's three weeks later, and I feel great right in time for me to give you the next treatment. Doctor: It’s the roller coaster that I'm not sure you're really looking forward to where you rise up again. But we're hoping that it's not as severe. You know, part of the goal for development of any new medicine is that you hope it's better than the current one. Patient: Okay. Family Member 1: What about sleeping? He’s having trouble sleeping right now? Doctor: No, do you think it has something to do with the steroids, Dexamethasone that you're taking? Because that kind of wakes people up. Patient: No. Ever since I've been on Erlida I've had trouble sleeping.

Patient: Okay. The pills that you told me to stop taking, should I go back on them? Doctor: No. You should not. You’re done. Patient: Okay. Doctor: We’re going to try a new drug, huh, that’s quite expensive, and we have to just be able to figure out if we can get it for you. Patient: Okay. Family Member: I appreciate it. Right. Patient: And how would I find out? Family Member 1: You do nothing. Family Member: You do nothing. They’ll call you. Patient: Oh, you’ll call me? Doctor: I’m not going to call you. The pharmacy will call you. Patient: The pharmacy, right. Family Member: Pharmacy. Right.

Patient: Was that Dr. Y or W? Family Member: I don’t know. Wayne maybe. I don’t know. Patient: Somebody made a comment that… Doctor: I think you know so all the studies, they try to go up to ten. They try to go up to ten. So we just try to chunk – you’re a little off cycle because you know we started off with the vitamin C thing so three more and then… Family Member: Seriously, we need three more? Doctor: Yeah. We want ten total. Patient: So you’re… Family Member: She’s serious. Doctor: No I am, I’m serious. Patient: Wake up, wake up, five more? Doctor: Yeah, total over time, but let’s just do one at a time. Patient: Oh.

Healthcare Professional: Uh, yes. CALLER Good afternoon, Infusion, this is M_. Doctor: M_ in charge? CALLER Yes. Family Member: Umm, will the, will the chemo class help me understand what my, what I need to do to protect him from whatever I’m supposed to protect him from? Doctor: Uh, yes, I mean, they will allow you to ask questions about anything you should be worried about, things you’ve heard, and you can go from there as to sort of whether should you worry or not worry. Umm. And so these are people that have been through it with a lot of people, so they should be able to guide you about what, you know, what’s real worry and what’s not real worry. Family Member: So, we’re normally the household that people come to for Christmas, probably twenty five people. Depending on where we are in the scheme of things, do I want that many people around? Doctor: Uh, right. So, when you pick your date for chemo with T_, Family Member: Hm Hmm. Doctor: you can sorta plan it out. So, the week that’s the scariest is if you get your chemo and Christmas and all those people are there seven to ten days after, that’s dangerous. Healthcare Professional: Mm, hmm. Doctor: Okay, but, if it’s the twenty, you know the eighteenth day of the cycle… Patient: So, apply the no-fly rule. Doctor: ‘Cuz again if

Family Member: Next time we’ll bring it all. Doctor: Yeah. Patient: My daughter-in-law, daughter-in-law works for F____. Doctor: Okay. So this is just to help with eye health? Patient: Well, my macular degeneration. Doctor: Yeah, typically, it’s okay. That works I think okay. I’m talking about the other stuff. You go to GNC. Family Member: Right. Doctor: And things like that where it looks good in the bottle but there’s no regulation on what’s inside. Remember we talked about how difficult that can be sometimes? Patient: Yeah. Doctor: And then I don’t know what’s going to happen if your liver poops out on me then we’re in trouble. Family Member: Right. Because it can affect his liver. Patient: Okay. And that was the same thing with the magnesium. Right?

Patient: No, she’s, she’s asking why wouldn’t people want to know. Doctor: Some people don’t want to know. Because now it’s an anxiety you gotta live with, and you know, it doesn’t necessarily mean one-hundred percent, but if you have it, it’s a very high chance that, particularly for breast cancer, you could get breast cancer. So. Patient: My, my children? Doctor: Your children. Patient: And my grandchildren? Family Member: Yes. Doctor: Everybody. Family Member: Not me, but yeah, them. Doctor: Right. Everybody that, so, you have one, it’s, it’s a mutation in the gene. You have two copies of the gene. It’s, you know, so there’s a one and four chance you could pass it on because two copies come from your, their mother, and so, the mother contributes one, you contribute one. Patient: Right. Right. Doctor: There’s a fifty/fifty chance, you could contribute a good one or bad one, so they -- you know – does that make sense? Patient: Right. Yeah, yeah, yeah, yeah, yeah I know all of that.

Patient: I can’t think of anything. Did you go to M___? Doctor: I went to ____ in M___. Patient: Okay, I see the gold and blue socks. Doctor: Oh no, I had an orange shirt on, so I put on orange socks. Patient: Okay, a maze of blue. Patient: Bless you! Doctor: Now the first-in-human study, I don’t think you’re eligible for it because of the liver. They only want bone disease. Uh- A lot of paperwork you’ve got read. Patient: Yeah, I hear that. Doctor: You can check with Dr. G___ Any notes from us - So let’s get a hold of your results from your most recent lung scan and your visit from pulmonology as to what they say or their thinking is behind your gasping spells. It’s important. Ah, your ARV7 is positive. That suggests that the Enzalutamide may not work very long. Patient: Yeah. Doctor: It’s likely in the near future that you’ll need new belly scan, abdominal scan, bone scan for us to more directly determine that the Enzalutamide is not benefiting you. So we tried to get your tissue sent for molecular testing but when we sent it, it wasn’t adequate for that sort of evaluation, so Dr. G__ may look at other options. Sometimes they can do another biopsy or do a blood test, Patient: Mm Hmm. Doctor: but that’s not as good, but it’s something that’s easy, though. So once we’ve determined that your cancer has continued to grow, the standard therapy would be to move you to chemotherapy and if the name docetaxel based chemotherapy. Alternatively we’ve got two studies. I got rid of one as I wrote that.

Family Member: - and my aunt has seizures Doctor: Oh. Family Member: And sometimes I have to keep her from swallowing her tongue- Doctor: That’s it. Yeah- Family Member: -by putting the spoon under there, so just letting it flow through. Doctor: -and again point six percent chance is really rare, but it’s probably if I look at all the side effect list it’s the one that would scare me the most if I was reading that form, Patient: Mm, hmm. Doctor: so I want to share it with you guys. Other than that, this is not like chemo. This is not like anything else. Patient: Yeah, right. Doctor: So the tiredness is the top three that really will be wiping you out. Sometimes it makes you feel so wiped out… Patient: Wait a minute, W__ I got a compliment for you Healthcare Professional: Uh, huh?

Family Member: Is that a (Pause35sec) Doctor: And your CAT scan (Pause15sec) Patient: Right. Doctor: They don’t really saw anything in your organs, your liver, all that looks good. Patient: Ah, okay. Doctor: And your bone scan (Pause6sec) Patient: Uh. Clinical study? (Pause5sec) Patient: My one meds is I wasn’t so sure that I could take. Doctor: So, yeah, when we saw you, you already had Abiraterone, enzaluta – Radium, docetaxel. And, so what we do next, uh, you know, the only thing you haven’t had is, uh, chemotherapy. Uh, another chemotherapy called Radia, uh – Jevtana, cabazitaxel would be standard treatment you could go through, and we were waiting because again, you’d finished your chemo – um, and uh Patient: Gotcha. Doctor: Um. So, uh. Patient: The enzalutamide. I, I don’t remember being on that.

Patient: Yeah. Doctor: Then you’ve got the Xarelto you take once a day? Patient: Yep. Doctor: Okay. Did I miss anything? Family Member: No. Patient: No. Doctor: No other vitamins? No other herbs? Family Member: Uh-uh. Doctor: Nothing else to move your bowels? Patient: No. Doctor: Did you already get your shot today? You got to go up and get it? Family Member: Yes. He’s gotten it.

Family Member: Right. Patient: Okay. Healthcare Professional: So per the protocol. Um, we have him come back in twenty-eight days, a month. I don’t know, I mean you probably won’t make a decision before that but we’ll have you come in on the twentieth. Patient: We will definitely have some idea though (chuckles) Healthcare Professional: Yeah, just as a follow-up off study to see how you’re feeling and everything off the drug, get another PSA um kinda see where things are. And um, I’ll let you guys finish up. Doctor: Well we need to have like a close-out visit and come up with the end-of-study visit, which is a Patient: Okay. Doctor: Yeah and so we’ll be looking to do that anyway. But I agree with you. We should make that decision you know before then. Patient: We will. I will talk to my wife. As a matter of fact when we leave here I’m going to head to the rehab. Doctor: Okay. Patient: And the four of us can kind of you know talk. But I think that’s the direction that we’ll probably go- Doctor: Once you have a clearer picture of you know which way you want to go, whether it’s radiotherapy with hormones for now or hormones plus or minus some secondary therapy which may work better, then I would also like to talk to you about some of the clinical trials in each of those categories. Since they are mutually exclusive right now. It’s kind of either like a radiotherapy based trial or hormone therapy plus something new. So once -

Patient: Back home laughs]] Doctor: Yeah, they are. Patient: laughs]] Okay. Doctor: This is your script for the PSA level and I need to give you um the scan order and everything so we’ll this same thing in three months when you come back. Patient: Okay, okay. Doctor: Okay? And let me look into your XGEVA injection. Patient: Okay.

Family Member: That’s okay. Doctor: Okay. Patient: So um I think we should take it one step at a time and keep all our options open. So uh stay with the Xtandi and the Lupron and bring in the BET. And uh I I’m gonna be getting it from Midtown rather from here and they’ll know that? Doctor: Oh well once – what I was going to propose is that I give you the copy of the consent. If you want you can read it and uh if you’re ready to sign today you can, or we can schedule all the testing in anticipation of putting you on the study and all of that downtown and then that same day you can come in and sign the consent and do all the testing necessary. That gives you some time to think it over talk it over before signing. Patient: And you said it would just be a couple days I’d have to be there? Doctor: The two days are the long days. There are other days that you would be coming in and I just… Patient: For how long? Doctor: Well that’s what the consent will give you the exact details Patient: Okay, Yeah. Doctor: of how many times a week, but the first few weeks typically are very, what this is called is a Phase I study. So it’s an earlier setting like I said the combination really we don’t have a good handle on what to expect in terms of toxicities, what dose, etc. So one of the side effects that has been noted so far is that the platelets can drop with this medication. So that is something of course the blood counts will be monitored anyway. Besides that kidney function, liver function, all that will also be monitored and checked. You go – undergo EKG monitoring that will be hard test like and echo before you start. So there is a lot of components. One additional component is that you probably will need to do a biopsy again as part of the study. Doctor: So that’s something to think about before you say yes or no. Patient: And does platelets dropping how would that affect me physically? Doctor: Well if it gets really low then it can cause bleeding and things like that -
